top_comment.text:
1) Does it curdle for anyone else when you add the egg to the butter and 
sugar mixture?
2) Basically there's nothing more to a "red velvet anything" than red food 
colouring, right?﻿
top_comment.author: SupermanSings

comments.text: +Jaylyn Saechao Thank you so much :)
comments.author: SupermanSings

comments.text:
To answer your first question it does curdle sometimes but it shouldnt if 
you beated your butter really well and you are only adding one egg at a 
time until its fully combined. To answer your second question no not really 
red velvet should only have a hint of chocolate and usually always have 
buttermilk and the raising agent it baking soda and vinegar but here she 
just added red food coloring so i guess its not really red velvet
comments.author: Jaylyn Saechao

top_comment.text:
but red food colouring in chocolate cookie dough doesn't make it red 
velvet. it just makes it red chocolate cookies. sorry, laura but this 
episode has let me down.﻿
top_comment.author: guardiangelrae

comments.text:
if you use natural cocoa, it will not give you a dark/blackish cookies/cake 
hence it will give you a nice red efffect,but if you use a dutch processed 
cocoa then you'll have trouble achieving the red color :)
comments.author: amocap

comments.text: Red velvet cake is essentially chocolate cake that is red.

comments.author: Mohd Taufik Mohammad

comments.text:
+guardiangelrae I love how you are berating Laura for adding food coloring

coloring. Then you go on to post a link to wikipedia which does nothing but

comments.author: nr98001

comments.text:
I think people are overreacting. It is ok to have an opinion and express 
it. He/she didn't curse Laura, didn't say she's an awful cook, simply 
didn't get what the title suggested, and I see nothing wrong with that. She 
changed a bit of the recipe and add the food colouring, and although I 
agree this doesn't make something a red velvet, it makes amazing cookies 
and has Christmas spirit along with it. People seriously need to calm down 
and know that this is a feedback, not a hater.
comments.author: Beatriz Corbetta Reis

comments.text:
You cannot make a cookie by how you make red velvet cake. The vinegar and 
buttermilk mixture would just not give you the consistency that a cookie 
dough requires. In essence, it is "red velvet" because it is a chocolate 
base with red coloring...it's just not the classic red velvet one makes as 
a cake or cupcake.
comments.author: alexandraxoxoxo11

comments.text:
+ericxohh food colouring enhances it, yes. some people use beetroot juice. 
i'm just wondering what's the point of creating a whole new recipe when you 
could take any chocolate cookie recipe and dump red food colouring in and 
call it "red velvet".
comments.author: guardiangelrae

comments.text:

comments.text:
This is red velvet... and the taste is very well different believe it or

comments.author: Nabiilah Bun

comments.text:
+Rudy Illuminati everyone? i beg to differ. it is the reaction of vinegar, 
buttermilk and cocoa powder that makes it a red velvet. in fact, the red 
you're supposed to get is the anthocyanin that is produced in an original 
red velvet recipe. so, no, laura's cookies aren't red velvet.
comments.author: guardiangelrae

comments.text:
thats literally what red velvet is..... thats how everyone in the world 
makes red velvet

My batter is sticking to my hands and getting all over the place and it's 
been in the fridge for over 3 hours now :( idk what's wrong but in going to 
leave it overnight and hopefully the texture will be better.﻿
top_comment.author: xesmee63x

comments.text:
This is probably really late but just a tip: what I did to prevent it from 
sticking was I scooped out my dough into my powdered sugar( note that it 
wasn't a prefect circle yet) 
I coated the dough completely, THEN I rolled it into a ball & it still 
turned out perfect & the dough didn't stick at all (: I also only left it 
in the fridge for 2 hrs 30 min too. :3
comments.author: polymerclaylova

comments.text:
It could be your butter! Make sure it's really butter and not margarine! 
Even sticks of butter are margarine! It takes a looottttttt longer for 
margarine to harden back in the fridge then it does actual butter....I have 
found this out by personal experience (if you buy the brand "imperial" 
butter that is NOT really butter lol and that stuff takes a full day plus 
over night to harden.
comments.author: Cora Quiroz

comments.text:
Yeah I'm going to flour my hands and I've left it overnight so hopefully it 
works!

comments.text:
mine did the same thing too. i probably didn't add enough flour. but i did 
use flour to roll them in balls to save them.

captions.text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and we are in the
full swing of holiday baking around here,

and I have to say you guys tag me in the most
incredible recreations of my recipes, and

I just love seeing every single one of them
but the one cookie that just gets tagged more

than any - that I get tagged in more than
any other cookie in the history of 'Laura

in the Kitchen' has been my chocolate crinkle
cookies.

It just seems that all of you love them, and
so many of you have made them and shared the

picture with me and I love it. And I've been
getting a lot of questions about making different

recreations - you know - different variations
of it so that you can recreate them at home.

And I thought well, we're in the holiday season,
I love red for the holiday season, clearly.

I love chocolate crinkle cookies, so what
better than to just make red velvet crinkle

kisses, that's what I call them, they're like
red velvet crinkle cookies with a little chocolate

kiss in the center. They are phenomenal and
they could not be easier. The ingredients

you'll need are some all purpose flour, baking
powder, salt, cocoa powder, I've got some

granulated sugar, some unsalted butter that's
been softened. I've got eggs, red food coloring
and some vanilla extract. That is it!

I'm going to make my dough in my standing
mixer fitted with a paddle attachment - it
makes life really easy.

Okay, I'm going to take my butter, which you
know I've got my oven turned on and I sit

my butter on the stove to get it nice and
soft so that it kind of melts around the edges
just a little bit but that's fine.

I'm going to add my sugar and my butter and
I'm going to let these cream together just
briefly.

I'm going to add my egg and a good splash
of vanilla extract, and I'm going to just

let that mix until it's really well incorporated.
I'll make sure to scrape the sides of the
bowl in just a minute.

Excellent. I'm just going to give my dry ingredients
a little mix here, doesn't have to be mixed

perfectly, and I will say that recently anytime
I use cocoa powder, I've been sifting it because,

I don't know about you, but more and more
of my containers of cocoa powder get chunkier

and chunkier, you know, when I buy a new one
so I like to sift it, I don't want to get

any big chunks of cocoa because it doesn't
get mixed well.

So I'm just going to put my dry ingredients
right in, try to get them all in there. Mix

them, get it on the side of the mixer, well
that's just going to have to do.

I'm really jolly so I'll be perfectly fine
cleaning it up.
Mix this together until it's combined.

Just going to add some red food coloring to
this because it will - even though you're

thinking well, that's brown, how's that - just
trust me, red food coloring, it works.

You can add as much as you want or until you
get the desired color that you're looking
for.

This is looking good, I always like to finish
my batter or my doughs by hand just to make
sure everything's mixed really well.

I'm going to pop this batter into a bowl,
cover it with plastic wrap and this has to

go in the fridge to set for about three hours
or you could even do this overnight but really

no less than three hours, otherwise your cookies
won't kind of hold the way they should, so

I'm going to get all this out of here, cover
it, pop this in the fridge for several hours
and then we'll move forward!

My cookie dough was in the fridge for about
four hours and now I have my oven pre-heated

to 350F, I've got some confectioner's sugar
here and I also have a baking sheet lined

with some parchment paper and I am ready to
rock and roll!

So I've got my ice cream scoop that's about
the equivalent of a tablespoon, I take some

of my cookie dough, pop that into your hand
like so, form it into a ball, pop that into

the confectioner's sugar, just like of like
the same thing like we did with the - shake
off the excess - like with our chocolate crinkles.

And then just put them a couple inches apart
on your prepared baking sheet - and that's
it!

Okay, these are coated and ready to go, I'm
going to pop them into the oven at 350F, they'll

be in there for about 10-12 minutes and then
I'll show you what to do a couple minutes
after they come out.

My cookies were in the oven for twelve minutes
and when you take them out, let them sit for

2 minutes then you're going to take a little
chocolate kiss - you can take really any piece

of chocolate you want, I just like this specific
one because it's really cute - and you press

it in the center and you hold it there just
for a second, because once the bottom of the

chocolate starts to melt, it kind of holds
itself in place. You want to make sure you

do this while the cookie is still warm, so
that's why I only like to wait 2 minutes and

they're just smelling like - like I don't
even know what right now.

So I'm just going to continue to do that and
let them cool completely.

Now you know I just, I just have to! And look,
watch.
Just - you feeling me?
I have no words!

You know, what I said on my chocolate crinkles,
where it's like a mixture of a cookie and

a brownie? Called it a 'brookie' - same thing
goes for this one.
Perfect.
Really perfect!

Really beautiful to look at, I mean look at
them.
How could you not fall in love?
I don't even know! How can you not love these?
I know you will.
I'm in love.
We need a few moments alone.

Now, you know I want to see your recreations
of these cookies all over social media because

sharing is caring and because it is the holidays,
and I always say I always love seeing your

recreations but I especially love seeing them
around this time of year because it really

feels like we're spending the holiday together.
Because, I don't know about you and your family,

but for me, all of our memories are made in
the kitchen. All of our traditions are in

the kitchen, it's just the best place to be,
it's where laughs are shared, memories are
made and I feel that way with you.

If you want to get this recipe go onto LauraintheKitchen.com
I hope you have enjoyed spending time with
me and here's a little kiss to you!

title: Red Velvet Crinkle Kisses Recipe - Laura in the Kitchen Episode 854
